title: Winter Travel: Snowy Destinations Attract Throngs of Tourists
text: - 60 percent of ski service bookings in China are from individuals born in the 1990s and after 2000, indicating a surge in snow-themed travel interest post-optimized COVID-19 measures and the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics. - Swiss luxury watchmaker IWC Schaffhausen, represented by brand ambassador Eileen Gu, supports young skiers, reflecting a commitment to children’s confidence and unity through sports, with events in Colorado and Hebei province. - Chinese travelers have fully booked group tours to Finland and shown increased demand for high-end hot springs, with Tuniu reporting 15 percent of overseas tour bookings are for outbound hot spring tours, including popular destinations in Japan, Iceland, Switzerland, Thailand, and Turkiye. “` With the recent optimization of COVID-19 strategies in China, the industry is observing a significant surge in the popularity of winter sports, especially skiing. This season, the market for snow-based tourism is expected to experience a noticeable rise in revenue, thanks to enhanced service offerings and a burgeoning interest from consumers. Skiing Becomes a Favored Pastime Among Youth - The 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics has sparked an increase in skiing interest among teens and children. - Skiers primarily consist of individuals born in the 1990s and 2000s, as reported by Tuniu, a travel agency based in Nanjing. - These age brackets represent 60% of skiing service bookings, with a growing trend of children skiing alongside their parents. Brands Capitalize on Skiing Enthusiasm - Luxury Swiss watchmaker IWC Schaffhausen hosted a skiing event featuring brand ambassador and freestyle skier Eileen Gu. - The event, aimed at young skiers, took place at Genting Snow Park in Zhangjiakou, with prior events in Colorado. - IWC emphasizes the importance of sports in building children’s confidence and unity. - The company sees China as a vital luxury market and is optimistic about its future operations there. Regional Trends in Skiing Popularity - Shanghai, Beijing, Nanjing, and cities in Guangdong province show high demand for skiing activities. - Indoor ski resorts and snow parks allow southern Chinese regions to engage in skiing year-round. - Northeast China, Yunnan, Guizhou, and the Xinjiang Uygur autonomous region are top domestic picks for snowboarders. - International destinations like Finland, Switzerland, Denmark, Norway, and Iceland are increasingly popular among Chinese travelers. - November and December tours to Finland reached full capacity, with bookings continuing into March. Emerging Trends in Winter Tourism - High-end hot springs are attracting young Chinese consumers during winter. - Tuniu is integrating traveler preferences with destination strengths, including hot spring resorts in tour packages. - Consumers seek diverse, personalized, and quality hot spring experiences. - Bookings for outbound hot spring tours are growing, with 15% of overseas tour orders in November. - Japanese hot springs in cities like Nagoya and Hakone, along with unique offerings in Iceland, Switzerland, Thailand, and Turkiye, are receiving increased bookings. zhuwenqian@Shanghaiist
